title-group.subtitle: Spontaneous Resolution of an Established Iatrogenic Vertebral Arteriovenous Fistula

article-meta.aff: 1Barts and the London NHS Trust, London, United Kingdom
2Great Ormond Street Hospital, London, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Ashok Adams, FRCR, Barts and the London NHS Trust, 32 The Spinney, High Wycombe, Bucks, United Kingdom. Email: ashokadams@hotmail.com

abstract.p: Vertebral artery injuries can complicate attempted cannulation of the internal jugular vein including arteriovenous fistula formation. Such a fistula may occlude spontaneously in the acute phase but once established, spontaneous occlusion is extremely unusual. To the best of our knowledge, this has not been reported in the medical literature. We present a case of a patient who developed a right-sided vertebral arteriovenous fistula following instrumentation of the neck vessels but formal angiography/intervention was declined. The reason to report this case is that follow-up magnetic resonance angiography was performed, with spontaneous resolution of the right-sided vertebral arteriovenous fistula occurring postoperatively between days 30 and 135. Endovascular treatment options are available but for those who decline intervention, this report highlights the fact that spontaneous resolution of vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can occur.

body.p: Vertebral artery injuries are a recognized complication of both puncture of the vertebral artery for angiographic purposes and attempted cannulation of the internal jugular vein.1,2 A range of vascular injuries can occur, including dissection and thrombosis as well as arteriovenous fistula formation because of the proximity of the vertebral artery to the adjacent vertebral veins. Spontaneous occlusion of arteriovenous fistulae is rare but has been reported with regard to spinal dural arteriovenous fistulae, and the mechanism for this finding has not yet been fully elucidated.3 To the best of our knowledge, spontaneous resolution of an established vertebral arteriovenous fistula has not been reported in the medical literature. We present a case of a patient who developed a right-sided vertebral arteriovenous fistula following instrumentation of the neck vessels before an elective procedure. The patient developed an embolic posterior circulation stroke during the postoperative period but formal angiography and intervention were declined and the patient was treated only with antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 75 mg once daily). Follow-up magnetic resonance angiography after 135 days showed complete resolution of the right-sided vertebral arteriovenous fistula. This report highlights the fact that spontaneous resolution of vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can occur.

sec.title: Case History
sec.p: We present a 9-year-old boy with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, confirmed on von Hippel-Lindau mutation screening, who had resistant hypertension despite medical treatment. The patient was admitted for an elective endoscopic resection of a phaeochromocytoma confirmed on biochemical testing, a meta-iodobenzylguanidine radioisotope study and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen. The surgical procedure was uneventful; however, postoperatively the patient developed a right-sided homonymous hemianopia.

The initial MRI study (18 days postoperatively) confirmed the presence of a subacute left occipital infarct (not demonstrating any restricted diffusion at this stage) and a normal magnetic resonance angiogram of the intracranial vessels.

Subsequent magnetic resonance angiography of the neck vessels identified prominent epidural veins in the right side of the spinal canal and prominent veins adjacent to the origin of the right vertebral artery from the subclavian artery (Figures 1 and 2). The right vertebral artery showed no imaging evidence of dissection, thrombosis, or luminal abnormality. The appearances were suggestive of a right-sided vertebral arteriovenous fistula with arterialization of the vertebral venous system at the thoracic inlet. Review of the operative notes identified technical difficulty with cannulation of the right internal jugular vein. The left-side occipital infarction was attributed to an embolic event and the patient was commenced on aspirin therapy (75 milligrams once daily). The patients’ family declined the offer of formal catheter angiography and interventional treatment. No further symptoms developed and a follow-up magnetic resonance angiogram study performed 135 days postoperatively demonstrated complete resolution of all the prominent flow voids within the epidural veins and adjacent to the origin of the right vertebral artery (Figure 3).

caption.p: Axial image from 3-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance angiogram. Prominent arterialized draining vein can be seen extending into the spinal canal via the intervertebral foramen (white line arrow).

Maximum intensity projection image from the 3-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance angiogram in a left anterior oblique projection (right vertebral artery highlighted by black arrowheads). Multiple vessels can be seen around the origin of the right vertebral artery (white line arrow). Note the large arterialized draining vein extending into the spinal canal (black arrow), with prominent veins noted within the right side of the spinal canal (white arrows).

Maximum intensity projection image from the follow-up 3-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance angiogram in the left anterior oblique projection. The multiple vessels around the origin of the right vertebral artery as well as the prominent vessels noted within the right side of the spinal canal are no longer present.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Arterial injuries are seen in approximately 15%-20% of all penetrating neck wounds but injuries to the vertebral artery represent only a small proportion of extracranial arterial injuries (<10%).4 This is due to its deep location, relatively small caliber, and the protection offered by overlying bone throughout most of its course.5,6 A range of vascular injuries, including transection, dissection, occlusion, and false aneurysm formation can result. Because of the proximity of vertebral artery and adjacent vertebral veins, penetrating injuries can also result in arteriovenous fistula formation. Kuttner first reported this in 1917 secondary to a gunshot wound, and the fistula was successfully treated by excision following proximal ligation of the vertebral artery.5 Iatrogenic vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can result from direct angiographic puncture of the vertebral artery or following attempted cannulation of the internal jugular vein. There are also reports of vertebral arteriovenous fistulae associated with fibromuscular dysplasia and neurofibromatosis.7 Fistulae secondary to needle puncture usually occur lower in the neck (near the fourth and fifth cervical vertebrae) whereas congenital and post-traumatic lesions tend to be higher and deeper (first and second cervical level).8

Vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can present clinically with a range of different symptoms and it is important to be aware of a delayed presentation following a penetrating injury.9 Symptoms may include tinnitus, cervical radiculopathy or even heart failure from shunting. High-flow fistulae often present with more severe symptoms, including hemorrhage, steal phenomena, intracranial venous hypertension, or embolic stroke, as in this case.10,11 Initial imaging for vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can be performed with Doppler ultrasound and the diagnosis may be suggested by arterial-flow wave forms in dilated veins. However, the exact site of involvement may be difficult to define and differentiation from other conditions, for example, arteriovenous malformations or vertebral artery stenoses, may be challenging.12 In our case, the vertebral arteriovenous fistula was identified with a standard 3-dimensional time-of-flight magnetic resonance angiogram. This provides a noninvasive method of imaging the extracranial vessels without the need for contrast administration and relies on magnetization of the incoming arterial protons with saturation of the down-flowing venous protons.13 This technique was favored over computed tomography (CT) angiogram in view of the age of the patient. CT angiography has been shown to correlate well with catheter angiography and has the benefit of faster scanning times with multiplanar capabilities.14 Conventional catheter angiography remains the gold standard imaging modality for vertebral arteriovenous fistulae because it provides excellent anatomic detail with hemodynamic information relevant for treatment planning.

Treatment is advised for symptomatic high-flow fistulae to prevent future bleeding, compressive radiculopathy/myelopathy, and congestive myelopathy.10 The aim of treatment is to eliminate the fistula while preserving the vertebral artery. This is achievable if there are well-defined single or multiple channels connecting the artery and vein. Open surgical treatment is now reserved for only the most complex cases. Vertebral arteriovenous fistulae can now be successfully treated via balloon occlusion with or without embolization aiming to obliterate the fistula using either a transarterial or transvenous approach.15–18 Vascular plugs and stent grafts have also been utilized with success.19

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Vertebral arteriovenous fistulae are a recognized but rare complication of neck instrumentation because of attempted central venous catheterization. A number of endovascular techniques are now available for treatment of vertebral arteriovenous fistulae, and this is advised for symptomatic high-flow fistulae. Spontaneous occlusion of a vertebral arteriovenous fistula is rare and has not been previously reported in the setting of an established vertebral arteriovenous fistula. This may be of importance for patients who decline endovascular intervention for diagnosis and treatment of vertebral arteriovenous fistulae.
